sections.title: Choosing the Right Business Structure
sections.subtitle: Legal and tax implications of different business entities

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: Common business entity types and their characteristics
How to choose the right structure for your business

sections.title: Business Entity Options
sections.content: The right business structure affects your taxes, personal liability, and administrative requirements. Common options include sole proprietorship, partnership, LLC, S-Corporation, and C-Corporation. Each has different implications for taxes, liability protection, and complexity.

points.title: Sole Proprietorship
points.description: Simplest structure, no legal separation from business, income taxed on personal return.

points.title: LLC
points.description: Flexible structure with liability protection, can choose tax treatment, more paperwork than sole prop.

points.title: Corporation
points.description: Separate legal entity with strong liability protection, double taxation unless S-Corp, more complex.

sections.title: Liability Protection Matters
sections.content: Without proper business structure, your personal assets could be at risk if your business faces legal issues. LLCs and corporations provide liability protection.

sections.title: Tax Considerations
sections.content: Different structures have different tax implications. S-Corporations avoid double taxation, LLCs offer flexibility in tax treatment, and sole proprietorships have the simplest tax filing. Consider both current and future tax situations when choosing.

sections.title: Choose Your Business Structure
steps: Assess your liability risks and need for personal asset protection
Consider your current and projected income for tax implications
Research the administrative requirements of each structure
Consult with a lawyer and accountant before making your final decision

sections.title: You Can Change Structures
sections.content: Many businesses start as sole proprietorships or LLCs and convert to corporations as they grow. Choose a structure that fits your current needs but be prepared to change as your business evolves.
